intro: Omphalocarpum laurentii, commonly known as the Florida burrplant, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Leguminosae, also known as the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its pod-like fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces small, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in the spring. Its fruit is a spiny, three-lobed capsule that contains several seeds, which are dispersed by animals or through mechanical means. The plant is often found in moist, sandy soils along streambanks and in wetlands, contributing to the ecological diversity of these habitats.
